head.title: Is It a Farm, Or a Factory?

hedline.hl1: Is It a Farm, Or a Factory?

abstract.p: John R Benemann letter on Sept 20 Op-Ed article by Robert K Kennedy Jr and Eric Schaeffer on pollution and public health risks of large animal feedlots; says solution is to produce methane gas and liquid fertilizers from animal wastes

block.p: ''An Ill Wind From Factory Farms,'' by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Eric Schaeffer (Op-Ed, Sept. 20), addresses the pollution and public health risks of large animal feedlots. There is a simple, economical and even profitable solution: producing methane gas and liquid fertilizers from animal wastes.

''An Ill Wind From Factory Farms,'' by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Eric Schaeffer (Op-Ed, Sept. 20), addresses the pollution and public health risks of large animal feedlots. There is a simple, economical and even profitable solution: producing methane gas and liquid fertilizers from animal wastes.

Methane gas can be readily converted to electricity. This technology was pioneered in the United States more than 20 years ago and is now widely used in Europe and elsewhere. But here, shortsighted policies and politics have limited its use.
Energy from animal wastes could contribute to our energy security and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and offers health and environmental benefits. We must encourage this technology.
JOHN R. BENEMANN Walnut Creek, Calif., Sept. 22, 2003
The writer is president of the Institute for Environmental Management, a not-for-profit group.
